sec.title: N/A
sec.p: Review
Quassinoids: Phytochemistry and antitumor prospect
Zhi-Kang Duan, Zhao-Jun Zhang, Shu-Hui Dong, Yu-Xi Wang, Shao-Jiang Song, Xiao-Xiao Huang *

Key Laboratory of Computational Chemistry-Based Natural Antitumor Drug Research &
Development , Liaoning Province ,
School of Traditional Chinese Materia Medica
, Shenyang Pharmaceutical University , Shenyang 110016, China
A R T I C L E I N F O

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Quassinoids
Chemical source
Diverse structures
Antitumor activity
Structure-activity relationships
A B S T R A C T

Quassinoids, originating from the oxidative degradation of tetracyclic tirucallane triterpene, are a diverse class of secondary metabolites identifying from nature mostly in Simaroubaceae family. The crucial pharmacological activities and structural complexity of quassinoids have long fascinated scientists due to their medicinal uses, infamous toxicity, and unique biosynthesis. In the past few decades, 482 quassinoids, assigned to 6 skeletons, have been isolated and identified from plants. The names, classes, molecular formula, and plant sources of these secondary metabolites are collated here. This review will be a detailed update of the naturally occurring quassinoids reported from the plant kingdom, providing an in-depth discussion of their diversity, antitumor activities, structure-activity relationship.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p:
The Simaroubaceae family includes 32 genera and more than 170 species of trees and brushes of pantropical distribution (
). The bitter taste of all parts of the plants of this family is a touchstone for botanic identification. In the beginning of 19th century, the bitter substances of
Quassia amara
were named as quassin ( E 1840). The complete structure and stereochemistry of quassin and analogues were established when nuclear magnetic resonance techniques were applied to determine the structure of natural products (Z et al., 1962, Z et al., 1961). With the development of separation, purification, and molecular identification technologies, a large number of natural quassinoids have been isolated and identified, and still attract the widespread attention for both their medicinal uses.

sec.title: 2. Biosynthetic pathway of quassinoids
3. Summary of distribution and classification of quassinoids
sec.p:
The vast majority of quassinoids have been isolated from Simaroubaceae family, with only nothospondin ( 131 ) was derived from
Nothospondias staudtii
which does not belong to Simaroubaceae family (
). The distribution of quassinoids in nature by source genus has been detailed and tallied in Fig. 2 and Table S 1. This review will cover C 26-, C 25-, C 20-, C 19-, C 18- and C 22- quassinodis according to the biosynthetic pathway and classes shown in Fig. 3.

C
26
-quassinoids (class A ): as a relevant biogenetic intermediate, they were isolated from
Eurycoma longifolia
and has been found to support how C 30 triterpenoids are degraded to C 25 -
quassinoids ( Yang et al., 2020 )
.

C 25 -quassinoids (class B ): the C 25 quassinoids constitute a small group within the quassinoids, which originated from C 26 quassinoids by losing one carbon at C-4. Nineteen C 25 -quassinoids are isolated and identified from Picasma , simaba and others species.

C 20 -quassinoids (class C-E): the category is the largest group and serves as the cornerstone for investigation of quassinoids. There are 390 members added in the last decade from Simaroubaceae family, involving three novel skeletons. The tetracyclic variety (class C ) does not have oxygenation at C-20, while the pentacyclic quassinoids (class D and E ) possess additional oxygenation at C-20 that allows for the formation of an additional ring between C-20 and C-11 or C-20 and C-13.

C 19 -quassinoids (class F ): structurally, are the second group of quassinoids, which was evolved from C 20 quassinoids. These quassinoids have been mainly isolated from
E. longifolia
,
Ailanthus altissima
and
Ailanthus excelsa
.

C 18 -quassinoids (class G ): the C 18 -quassinoids are a relatively small class, only six C 18 -quassinoids were isolated from Simaroubaceae
E. longifolia
and
Samadera indica
.

C 22 -quassinoids (class H ): this classification has the characteristics of C 20 -quassinoids, but the partial carbon skeletons have changed. Three secondary metabolites are isolated from
Picrolemma sprucei
and
Picrolemma pseudocoffea
.
4. Phytochemical investigations
4.1. C 26 - quassinoids (class A )

In 2020, Wei-Qun Yang et al . reported isolation of the first C 26 quassinoids longifolactone A (1) and longifolactone B (2), obtained from the roots of
Eurycoma longifolia ( Yang et al., 2020 )
. Structurally, compounds 1 and 2 possess an intact gem -dimethyl unit at C-4, making them the first members of a novel class of quassinoids featuring a C 26 backbone (as shown in Fig. 4 ).
4.2. C 25 - quassinoids (class B )

This class B is structurally characterized by the occurrence of a furan ring at C-17, and examples have been isolated from various
Picrasma
,
Eurycoma
, S oulamea ,
Simaba
,
Quassia
,
Hannoa
and
Odyendea species.
It is worth noting that two novel skeletons have been identified, according to whether the furan ring are form between C-21 and C-23 (class B 1), or C-17 and C-23 (class B 2).

Odyendene (19) and odyendane (20) Fig. 7 feature an unusual Δ 20,22 double bond, which were isolated from
Odyendea gabonensis ( Forgacs et al., 1985 )
. In 2014, Fang et al. reported a new 20
S
quassinoid perforalactone A (21) with a unique cagelike 2,4-dioxaadamantane ring system, which was not usually encountered in the natural products of the plant kingdom (
). Meanwhile, a new biosynthetic related quassinoids perforalactone B (22) was identified from
Harrisonia perforate ( Fang et al., 2015 )
.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: 4.3. C 20 - quassinoids

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: In the last decades, there are 300 new members added, involving two novel skeletons: tetracyclic and pentacyclic. The tetracyclic variety does not have oxygenation at C-20, while the pentacyclic quassinoids possess additional oxygenation at C-20 that allows for the formation of an additional ring.

sec.title: 4.3.1. Tetracyclic C 20 - quassinoids (class C )
4.3.2. Pentacyclic C 20 - quassinoids (class D and E )
sec.p: Compared to tetracyclic quassinoids, the pentacyclic C 20 -quassinoids present esters at C-15 closely related with cytotoxicity. According to whether the oxide bridges are attached at C-11 and C-13, they may be subdivided into two subtypes, class C (210–325) and D (326–418). Quassinoids 210–325 are characterized by an oxide bridges between C-20 and C-13. According to the degree of unsaturation of ring A , the class is further discussed ( Figs. 14 - 22 ).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: 4.4. C 19 - quassinoids (class F)

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
C 19 -quassinoids is the second group of quassinoids. The skeleton of these compounds evolved from C 20 -quassinoids through lose C-16 carbon (class E1-3) or C-1 carbon (class E4) ( Fig. 23 ). In 1985, Judith Polonsky and his team have explained the possible biogenetic pathway of C 19 -
quassinoids ( Polonsky et al., 1985 )
. Similarly, under oxidative conditions, C20-quassinoids might undergo cleavage, decarboxylatio and formation of the lactone in succession.

sec.title: Orphanage
Orphanage
Orphanage
Orphanage
sec.p: 4.5. C 18 - quassinoids (class G)

sec.title: Orphanage
Orphanage
sec.p: 4.6. C 22 - quassinoids (class H)

sec.title: Orphanage
5. Antitumor activities of quassinoids
sec.p: The experimental pharmacological and clinical investigations carried out during the past several years have shown that the quassinoids have various biological effects including antitumor, antimalarial, anti-inflammatory, antifeedant, insecticidal, amoebicidal, antiulcer and herbicidal activities (Fiaschetti1 et al., 2011, Hou¨el et al., 2013). The quassinoids are renowned for two major pharmacological activities: their antitumor and their antimalarial potential (Hou¨el et al., 2013). In this review, the development of antitumor drugs from quassinoids was summarized. The structure-activity relationships (SAR) and the mechanism of action are also discussed.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: 5.1. Cytotoxicity of quassinoids

sec.title: Orphanage
Orphanage
sec.p:
Su et al. tested the cytotoxicity of compound 188, 210–212, 220–221, 236, 263–265, 284, 288 and 312 (class D C 20 -quassinoids) again human cancer cell lines A549, MCF-7 and Bel-7404 (
). Compound 210, 211 and 220 exhibited noticeable cytotoxicity against cancer cell lines MCF-7 and Bel-7404 (IC 50 < 10 μM), while compound 188, 221, 263, 265, 284, 288 and 312 were found to be inactive towards all the tested cell lines (IC 50 > 50 μM). In addition, as shown in Fig. 29 , an α , β -unsaturated ketone group at C- 2 in ring A are the common structural requirements for optimum cytotoxicity, such as compound 210, 211 and 220. The quassinoids with an ester group at C-15 showed relatively good activity. Comparing the compounds 220 and 221, it was found that the activity of quassinoids with a – CH 2 OH group at C-13 were poor.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Ye Q. M. et al. tested the cytotoxicity of compound 210–211, 220, 234, 239, 253–254, 256, 258, 268, 284–285, 287–288, 300–301 and 311–312 (Class D C 20 -quassinoids, as shown in Fig. 30 ) (
). Among them, compound 210, 211, 234 and 239 with an α , β -unsaturated ketone group at C- 2 in ring A exhibited significant cytotoxicity against cancer cell lines A549 and MCF-7 (IC 50 < 1 μM). Among the quassinoids glycosides tested, only compound 258 showed noticeable cytotoxicity.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Wang Y. and his team reported the cytotoxicity of class C quassinoids 173, 169–170, 201, class E quassinoids 195, 338, 342, 350, 354–355, 358, 361, 388–389 and a C 19 -quassinoid 458 against Human cancer cell lines HepG2, Hep 3B and R-HepG2 (as shown in Fig. 31 ) (
). In three types of quassinoids, the class D showed noticeable cytotoxicity, but the class B C 20 -quassinoids and C 19 -quassinoids had no cytotoxicity. This suggest that the oxygen bridge ring between C-8 and C-11 may contribute to the cytotoxicity of quassinoids. Besides, the compound with an α , β -unsaturated ketone group at C- 2 in ring A showed more potent activity, such as compounds 338, 350, 388 and 389. And when an ester group at C-15 of quassinoids, their cytotoxicity showed more active, such as compounds 342 and 350. The order of cytotoxicity of compound 338, 388 and 389 is: 388 > 338 > 389. This indicated that the isopentenyl at C-6 may contribute to the cytotoxicity of quassinoids, but there must have an α , β -unsaturated ketone group at C- 2 in ring A.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Three types of quassinoids, including
C 20
-quassinoids,
C 19
-quassinoids and
C 18
-quassinoids, were all tested for cytotoxicity activity against the metastatic human HT-1080 fibrosarcoma cell line by Miyake and his team (
). The result showed that either
C 20
-quassinoids or
C 19
-quassinoids, as long as the quassinoids with an α , β -unsaturated ketone group at C- 2 in ring A , their activity were more potent, such as compound 178, 186, 333 and 420. For class B
C 20
-quassinoids 178, 181, 186 and 198, the β - OH group at C-12 or/and – OH at C-6 may reduce the cytotoxicity. For
C 19
-quassinoids, the cytotoxicity of these compounds was influenced by the lactone at between C-12 and C-14 or lactone at between C-11 and C-13. Compound 443 with a lactone at between C-12 and C-14 showed weak activity, it indicated that the location of lactone might be an important factor of cytotoxicity. The – OH group at C-2 would reduce the cytotoxicity of
C 19
-quassinoids, comparing with the quassinoids with an α , β -unsaturated ketone group at C- 2 in ring A , for example: compounds 404 and 443. The double bond would enhance the cytotoxicity activity, such as compound 434. However, the
C 18
-quassinoids had no cytotoxicity. The detail information is shown in Fig. 32
.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: 5.2. Antitumor activity of quassinoids and mechanism of action

sec.title: Orphanage
Orphanage
sec.p:
After 2011, several researchers have studied the pharmacological mechanism of action. Eurycomanone (349) affects the expression of various cellular proteins which have multifunctional roles in cell proliferation and survival and are also associated with cancer development, progression and metastasis (
). The studies showed that eurycomanne induced apoptosis via p53 pathway by increasing the expression of pro-apoptotic Bax and decreasing anti-apoptotic Bcl-2 proteins; and the compound also targets other pathways affecting cell replication notably, including p53 tumor suppressor gene, the lung cancer cell markers hnRNP A2/B1, annexin I and probibitin. But its lipid solubility, oral bioavailability and the formation for effective delivery need improvement.

sec.title: Orphanage
Orphanage
sec.p:
Bruceantinol (211) is a novel therapeutic STAT3 inhibitor that could be used either or in combination with MEK inhibitors for the treatment of human colorectal cancer (
). The experiment results showed that bruceantinol strongly inhibited STAT3 DNA-binding ability (IC 50 = 2.4 pM), blocked the constitutive and IL-6-induced STAT3 activation in a dose- and time-dependent manner, and suppressed transcription of STAT3 target genes encoding anti-apoptosis factors (MCL-1, PTTG1, and survivin) and cell-cycle regulators (c-Myc). In addition, bruceantinol effectively sensitized MEK inhibitors through repression of p-STAT3 and MCL-1 induction, known resistance mechanism of MEK inhibition.

sec.title: 5.3. Summary and perspectives
sec.p:
In the last decade, 482 quassinoids, including 6 skeletons: C 26 , C 25 , C 20 , C 19 , C 18 and C 22 were identified from plants mostly in the Simaroubaceae family. The distribution and research of C 20 -quassinoids are the most extensive quassinoids and the studies on C 26 -, C 18 - and C 22 - quassinoids are rarely reported. The analysis of distribution of quassinoids in Simaroubaceae family revealed that different plants contain different types of quassinoids. The plant with the most quassinoids reported is
Brucea javanica
, the main quassinoids is class C and C C 20 - quassinoids. And
E. longifolia
is the main source of C 19 -quassinoids. A larger number of class C C 20 -quassinoids have been reported on the phytochemistry research of Picrsma quassioids . Besides, the isolation of
Ailanthus altissma
and
Eurycoma longifolia
was obtained numerous class E C 20 -quassinoids. Moreover, only two C 26 -quassinoids have been reported from
Eurycoma longifolia
.

Quassinoids with structurally unique and complex natural products exhibit a wide range of interesting chemical properties and biological. The high toxicity of quassinoids has hampered their development into new therapeutic agents. In the studies on the structure-activity relationship of quassinoids, the cytotoxicity compounds have the following characteristics: (1) an α , β -unsaturated ketone group at C- 2 in ring A ; (2) an ester group at C-15; (3) class C C 20 -quassinoids exhibited lower cytotoxicity; (4) C 19 -quassinoids could be a potential source of antitumor drugs; (5) quassinoid glycosides may have a negative effect on cytotoxicity activity. As for the other three types of quassinoids ( C 18 , C 22 , C 25 ), the samples are too small to be included in the discussion.

Studies on the pharmacological mechanism of quassinoids indicate that these compounds have the potential to be antitumor drugs. In the current study, bruceantinol (211), bruceantin (212), dehydrobruceine B (277), eurycomanone (349) and other quassinoids have shown great potential for treating cancer. Nevertheless, no drug has been developed so far from these substances. Moreover, the clinical experiments of bruceantin have shown that it has serious toxic and side effects (hypotension, nausea, vomiting and fever). Whether all quassinoids have similar severe toxicity requires further clinical studies. The chemical analysis of the components of the quassinoids has produced a large number of samples, but systematic studies on their pharmacological activities are lacking. A considerable portion of the antitumor of quassinoids remains unknown. And their lipid solubility, oral bioavailability and pharmacokinetic study are only in their infancy. In brief, the research for quassinoids needs to continue.
Funding

This work was financially supported by the National Nature Science Foundation (81872767) of the People’ s Republic of China , Career Development Support Plan for Young and Middle-aged Teachers in Shenyang Pharmaceutical University (ZQN2018006) and the Project of Innovation Team (LT2015027) of Liaoning of the People’ s Republic of China .

sec.title: Declaration of competing interest
sec.p: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interest interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

sec.p: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2021.112769.
